 If people didn't take the "believe it was possible" approach, there would probably not have been nearly as many scientific discoveries in history. many discoveries and conclusions often weren't come to by accident, they were come to because a scientist wanted to see if it was there/would happen. That too was a belief that something was possible before questioning it and examination/investigation. For that reason I don't think belief that something is possible is a problem in terms of an empirical approach. For instance, extrasolar planet-hunting astronomy didn't just happen by accident, it happened (and continues) on the basis that scientists believe it is possible something might be there.

 However in the Messiah program he goes a bit more serious and shows how a lot of the techniques he uses in his show are used (unintentionally a lot of the time) in the US, he attempts to get four people to endorse him as genuine; a evangelical faith healer (where he does the conversion by touch), a medium (doing the cold reading thing), an alien abduction group (where he demonstrated the psychic powers he had been granted) and a new age theorist (with a 'dream recorder'). The last four all endorsed him whilst the evangelical asked to meet him a second time, so he revealed himself to be a fake as was the original idea of the show.

My point is simply that "never" is an absolute term and it only takes one to invalidate it. Your experience is limited and a short search of the net will give you the necessary experience.
 
 As I stated, the veracity of those items is not really in question as we are speaking of someone's experience and we cannot really argue it. INRI reports his experience. You argue that stating your experience does not comport. My point is that your experience is limited and you could find more if you tried.
 
 EF
sinjin

They self report as atheists. This point is actually irrelevant, as you say that in your experience God never appears to atheists. You use the terms never and "in your experience". My point is simply that "never" is an absolute term and it only takes one to invalidate it. Your experience is limited and a short search of the net will give you the necessary experience.
 
 As I stated, the veracity of those items is not really in question as we are speaking of someone's experience and we cannot really argue it. INRI reports his experience. You argue that stating your experience does not comport. My point is that your experience is limited and you could find more if you tried.
 
 EF

 You are of course correct. I appreciate your clarity. I will see if I can find some of those formerly self reported atheist converts.
INRI

An open mind would suggest that one is not certain what is "true". Please elaborate.

 
 LOL, The Irony of it all.
 
 you have no Idea how many times I have heard non christians say Christians do not have an open mind.
 
 "oh you christians are not very open minded when it comes to abortion"
 
 "Christianity is not very open minded towards Homosexuality"
 
 
 open mindedness is regarded by them as something to be proud of...
 
 Yet when open minded is use in the context of seeking God it is regarded as a disability a unableness to determine what is true, it amazes me how non Christians and atheists can be so sure God does not exist yet they can not even determine what is true about the nature of Abortion and homosexuality
sinjin

Yet when open minded is use in the context of seeking God it is regarded as a disability a unableness to determine what is true, it amazes me how non Christians and atheists can be so sure God does not exist yet they can not even determine what is true about the nature of Abortion and homosexuality
You feel you know truth. Are you open-minded to the idea you might be wrong?
 For instance: What is the truth concerning why God would allow infants to die horrible deaths in car accidents, bombings, famines, etc.?
Tastyfish

open mindedness is regarded by them as something to be proud of...
 
Indeed, 'an open mind is like a fortress with its gates unlocked and unguarded.'
 
 I would say that you have a slightly odd definition of open mindedness, its a willingness to look at a situation objectively rather than the ability to beleive something. A willingness to review your opinion based off new evidence - using the bible as the sole basis on whether an action is right or wrong (as in the case of homosexuality) clearly shows you can not be open minded on the topic as you refuse to accept that there is/or even will ever be any additional evidence to weigh up.
 
 On the otherhand, I don't think atheism is not open minded toward the existance of god - should new evidence appear that makes it clear and obvious that there is a god then most would be willing to change their mind. However just because new evidence to consider does appear (such as testamonials from converts) doesn't mean that still refusing to accept the existance of god reveals you to be closeminded on the topic, the evidence just isn't good enough as it doesn't stand up to contradictory evidence or can be explained away by other means.
Winston Smith

Actually, yes they can. What specific thoughts no, but what areas of the brain are active, yes.
 
 There is a technique that using an MRI that actually can be used as a lie detector test, where the subject is shown objects, and areas of the brain will light up if it is a familar object.

 
 can you read the thoughts? Of course not, just brain activity.
trebor

can you read the thoughts? Of course not, just brain activity.

 
 The brain pattern for when somethign is reconized is known. So, the device can 'read thoughts' in that respect. If an object from a crime scene is shown to a suspect, and the brain 'lights up' in the proper sequence, it reads the thoughts of the person,and can highlight a suspect to the police.
 
 What are thoughts but brain activity??
Yossarian

I agree with Simone:
The only thing to know is that one can't know.

 Or, to put it another way, "The reason I am here is because if I wasn't, I wouldn't be here to ask why I'm here."
 Chew on that for awhile.
 
 But, to use a car as an analogy just doesn't work for me. I've seen cars, some of them quite strange. Asking me to believe in the possibility of a pink fuzzy one outside is not the same as asking me to believe in God, and God, cuz I've never seen one.
 
 Tastyfish wrote:
You should check out a program by Derran Brown called 'Messiah' if you get the chance, he converts a whole room of atheists to christianity by touch.

 ...and that is truly frightening. Does he give them all a nice, big glass of refreshing Kool-Aid first?
 
The idea of the show was to demonstrate that people tend to hear only things that support their own ideas and ignore contradictory beliefs.

 That is simply not true. emoticon_xangel 
 
 epaphras_faith wrote:
I was open minded enough in my atheism to look at what was true and to consider that maybe I did not understand the bible as I thought I did.

 And wouldn't that have made you agnostic, not atheist? Atheists are not at all open-minded. They claim God doesn't exist, period. Unless, I suppose, as Tastyfish pointed out, "new evidence appear[s] that makes it clear and obvious that there is a god."
 
 Winston Smith wrote:
hard to swallow? thoughts can not be detected by MRI scans either

 ...but DARPA would disagree with you.
 Then you asked, "can you read the thoughts? Of course not, just brain activity." But how can we "prove" that thoughts are anything other than brain activity?!? ...as Trebor pointed out.
Winston Smith

TREBOR:
 there is no way you can 'read' the thoughts; you are only making a connection based on previous events. a reading of an instrument is not the reading of thoughts but just of brain activity.
Adept

not the reading of thoughts but just of brain activity.

 
 Thoughts are simply brain activity. If you can read and measure that activity, you can read and measure thoughts.
Winston Smith
so you can tell me what I am thinking by reading my brain activity??
thelmoose

The brain pattern for when somethign is reconized is known. So, the device can 'read thoughts' in that respect. If an object from a crime scene is shown to a suspect, and the brain 'lights up' in the proper sequence, it reads the thoughts of the person,and can highlight a suspect to the police.
 
 What are thoughts but brain activity??

 
 Neuroscience has some along way. With functional scanning (functional MRI for example) one can see which areas of the brain have variable metabolic rates which relate to brain "activity." Different types of stimuli will "light up" areas relegated to certain functions. I agree with you to some extent; however, it is not exactly clear what these objective phenomena really "mean". Brain activity consists of neurophysiologic activity, and "thoughts" are part of that, but the stage of the game is relatively crude at this point.
Tastyfish

so you can tell me what I am thinking by reading my brain activity??
 
 Not currently, but do you believe your thoughts are in any way seperate from what is occuring physically in your brain?
Adept

so you can tell me what I am thinking by reading my brain activity??

 
 Yes. The only question is how accurately can we read brain activity.
